_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Daily inspection and yearly monitoring and equipment testing based on scheduled maintenance procedures
_prev_prog_3.Description: There are standard operating procedure that prevent any over filling of the  liquid storage tank, and daily visual inspections of all system. These procedures require that individual be trained and have experience in the operation of the blow-down procedure, and equipment operation. All critical components within the system have high and low level check. With failure of the visual monitoring system there is a series of pressure relief valves on the tank systems and supply line to the liquid concentrate storage tank. Any instance where liquid product, back up into the compressor it will automatically shut down the entire operation, activate the alarm system and notify all site personnel by the automatic dialing system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Program
                                                             Executive Summary
                                
                                                  National Fuel Gas Supply Corporation
                                                        Lamont Compressor Station

  1)  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:
  
       It is the policy of National Fuel Gas to provide and maintain safe and healthful working
       conditions and follow sound operating practices that will safeguard our employees, our
       customers, our community, and environment. We will strive to comply with legislative 
       requirements and eliminate any foreseeable hazards which may result in losses, damage to
       property, personnel injury and illnesses, and the environment.
    
      The Accidental Release Prevention Policy at the facility is embedded in our overall
      approach to planning, design and construction intended to minimize hazards; and the
      training of all personnel in proper operation, maintenance and inspection procedures with
      emphasis on awareness and practices to minimize hazards and avoid accidents.  The
      Emergency Response Policy is to identify potential hazards at the facility, and develop and
      implement a plan to respond to emergency events including, but not limited to fire,
      accidents or injury.  The Emergency Response Plan includes identification of responders
      and their duties, and procedures for notification of responders including fire department,
      evacuation, shutdown, communications, and medical response.

2)  Stationary Source:
  
      The purpose of the Lamont Compressor facility is to withdraw field gas from a nearby
      production well gathering system, remove hydrocarbon liquid and moisture from the gas,
      raise the pressure of the gas, and deliver it into a natural gas transmission piping s

ystem.
      The operation is carried out by two interrelated, but distinct,  processes. The process that is
      covered by this Risk Management Program (RMP) is a secondary function at the facility. 
      This is a process for storage of water and hydrocarbon liquids (liquid product) which are
      stripped from the natural gas, and stored at 20 psig in a 15,000 gallon storage tank until it
      is shipped.  Prior to shipping the liquid product is transferred to an 8,000 gallon tank to
      facilitate tranfer to a tank truck at atmospheric conditions.  During the winter, water which
      settles to the bottom of the 15,000 gallon tank is transferred to the 8,000 gallon tank to
      avoid freeze ups.  A closed glycol loop passes through this tank to supply waste heat from
      the compressor engine cooling system.  The other process, which is the primary process at
      this facility, is a natural gas compression process which is not covered by this RMP.
    
      In this other process natural gas is withdrawn from the gathering system, compressed and
      delivered to a high pressure transmission system.  The natural gas is compressed in three
      stages, and it is cooled between the first and second stages and after the final stage. 
      Liquids that are formed due to compression and cooling are temporarily stored in drip pots. 
      During each shift operators manually open valves for a few minutes to drain the pots and
      blow the liquid product into the storage system.





    
3)  Regulated Substances:
  
    The liquid product is a flammable liquid, and consists of an approximate a mixture of:
    
          I)    Water
          ii)   Butane
          iii)  Iso-Butane
          iv)  Pentane
          v)   Other organics

      Since the analytical composition of this liquid product varies depending on the gas mixture
      extracted from the production field, analytical analysis was performed to determine a
      general composition for

this liquid product. This product is stored at approximately 20
      pounds per square inch pressure in the liquid product storage tank.
    
4)   Worst Case Release Scenario:
  
      The worst case release scenario, as defined by the EPA, was developed based on a release
      of the largest quantity of liquid that the storage tank could possibly hold, the evaporation of
      the total quantity, and an explosion of the vapor cloud.  The explosion is assumed to reach
      an end point distance based on a model of an explosion of  TNT in a quantity  that has 10
      percent of the estimated energy available in the liquid product.
    
      This scenario is based on the release of 15,000 gallons (67,000 pounds) of liquid product,
      total evaporation, and explosion of the vapor cloud with an effective radius of 0.33 miles.
      This scenario is estimated to affect an offsite population of 5.
    
      The modeling used for end point determination was based on the RMP Off-site
      Consequence Analysis Guidance (OSA) Document, Published Friday, May 24,1996.  In
      review of the OSA Document, it was determined to use an atmospheric over-pressure of
      1.0 pounds per square inch as the end-point for the release.  This end-point was chosen as
      the threshold because of the potential for serious injury to people as a result of property
      damage caused by the explosion, glass from shattered windows or falling debris.

5)  Alternative Release Scenario:

     This alternate scenario is a release of a quantity of the regulated substance from a vessel or
     process line failure which is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario. This release
     is assumed to result in a vapor cloud containing the total quantity of the substance between
     the Upper and Lower flammability limits which explodes and impacts offsite receptors.
    
     The alternative scenario was based on the release of the actual maximum contents of the
     liquid product

storage tank, 9,000 gallons or approximately 41,000 pounds of liquid
     product, total evaporation, and explosion of the vapor cloud with an effective radius of 
     0.28 miles.  This scenario is estimated to affect an offsite  population of 5.
    
     The quantity of 9,000 gallons was based on the standard operational procedure for this site
     to limit the volume in the tank to 60 percent of  capacity.
    
     The modeling used for end point determination was based on the RMP OSA Document. 
     From the OSA Document, it was determined to use an atmospheric over-pressure of 1.0
     pounds per square inch as the end-point for the release. This end-point was chosen as the
     threshold because of the potential for serious injury to people as a result of property
     damage caused by the explosion, glass from shattered windows or falling debris.

6)  General and Chemical -Specific Accidental Release Prevention Program:
    
      All personnel are trained in proper operation procedures of all equipment.  Training and
      testing are conducted on-the-job. Any individual who works in this process must have
      extensive mechanical abilities, and is thoroughly tested and evaluated in the processing
      operations as part of the accident release prevention program 
    
      Valves and other equipment are maintained, tested and replaced in-kind if necessary.  
      Maintenance is performed on all compressors and systems based on written manufacturers'
      or facility procedures.  The operational systems have general monitoring, maintenance and
      inspection performed to ensure optimum performance.
    
      This facility is normally in operation 24 hours a day with operations personnel present. 
       Personnel  monitor  system operating parameters and equipment several times during each
      shift.  Detailed visual inspection of the storage process for equipment leaks or other
      possible failure is conducted on both a daily and monthly

basis
    
      The storage tanks are equipped with level indicators and pressure relief valves.  In the
      unlikely event that the liquid product storage tank was overfilled and flowed into the
      compressor system, the compressors would shut down and alarms would automatically
      activate. 
    
      The main liquid product storage tank which has a maximum capacity of 15,000 gallons is
      never filled to full capacity. The standard operational procedure for this site is that the
      liquid product storage tanks will only be filled to sixty (60) percent of  total volume which
      is approximately 9,000 gallons.  Approximately one 2,100 gallon truckload per month of
      the liquid product is shipped when the facility is in full operation.  The transport company,
      Heath Oil, has specific loading/unloading procedures which are used by the tank truck
      driver to prevent spill.
    
      There is minimal motor vehicle exposure to the liquid product storage tank. The traffic
      pattern and required slow speed  reduce the potential exposure from vehicular traffic. All
      personnel entering the facility first must check in with the site operations personnel.
    
7)  Five Year Accident History:
  
     To date this facility has had no release of liquid product, or other related incidents which
     caused off-site injuries, public evacuations, or any instances where personnel, the public, or
     the environment have been placed in danger from this operation.
 
8)  Emergency Response Program:
  
      There is a written Emergency Response Plan for the facility.  The plan includes
      requirements and recommendations for the control of emergency occurrences including,
      but not limited to fire, accidents or injury.   
    
      This Emergency Response Plan is intended to establish a controlled and orderly means of
      response and control of emergencies in order to avoid unnecessary panic, injury, or death. 
      During emergenc

ies, existing hazards can change quickly, therefore the Emergency
      Response Plan is intended as a guideline for emergency response.
    
      A emergency response organization has been established  to implement the plan, and is
      staffed by a director, assistant director, emergency responders.  The director is responsible
      for maintaining the plan, training and drills, overseeing facility emergency response
      including notifying and coordinating with local emergency responders, shut down of the
      gas compression system, maintaining and operating communications and communication
      systems including the fire alarm system, and evacuation,.  The assistant director assists the
      director and assumes his post in his absence or incapacity.  The emergency responders are
      responsible for assisting in the evacuation of the facility. 

      The local fire department has visited the facility to review potential hazards at the site, and
      to review coordination of firefighting and other emergency response procedures.
 
      Site personnel are trained in "first person on scene" response procedures to assess medical
      emergencies in order to communicate with medical emergency responders.  Personnel who
      are trained in emergency first aid and may voluntarily care for injured employees. 
    
      There are also notices available at the site regarding emergency contacts.  They are posted
      clearly at both entrances, the contacts are:
    
         1)   Emergency Response Director:       Mr. Mike Kasprzak     814-827-5701
    
         2)  Assistant Response Director:           Mr. Mike Kulka          814-837-9145  Ext: 236
    
         3)  Emergency Responders:                  Mr. Bill Cecchetti        814-837-6720
                                                                       Mr. Mike Jamerson      814-837-672
    
         4)  Foremen:                                          Mr. Joe Rostan            814-837-9312

5)  National Fuel Gas Supply                Office:                         800-634-5440  Ext: 2360
                     Corporation                                Buffalo Office:           716-827-2374
    
9)  Planned Changes to Improve safety:
  
      The process covered by this RMP is a very basic storage process.  All facility operations
      are periodically reviewed and up-dated as necessary.   Presently, no changes to the
      operation or configuration of this process are planned.
